name: NPR
text:
A New York City police officer has been suspended after video appeared to show him using a chokehold during an arrest. 

Chokeholds have been banned in the city since 1993, and a new state law making it a felony was signed this month.
https://t.co/xH5gfiECvd

name: NPR
text:
The director Joel Schumacher, known for his hit '80s movies "The Lost Boys" and "St. Elmo's Fire," died Monday morning in New York City from cancer. He was 80 years old.
https://t.co/cT8TqJU7qT

name: NPR
text:
The FBI has joined the investigation into who left a noose in the racetrack garage of Bubba Wallace — the only Black driver in NASCAR's top circuit.

NASCAR plans to ban the perpetrators from the sport for life. 
https://t.co/txEwaKs4Ig

name: NPR
text:
Black Americans enrolled in Medicare were hospitalized with COVID-19 at rates nearly four times higher than their white counterparts, according to new federal data.

Disparities were also striking among Hispanics and Asian Americans.
https://t.co/tWjiL5rFqx

name: NPR
text:
Data shows police officers “regardless of their race” have similar implicit biases — especially about Black people.

"We can't make the assumption that simply because a person is Black that they're going to know about the neighborhood," says a researcher. https://t.co/12KP6Pf7Ci

name: NPR
text:
A Barcelona opera reopened with a performance of Giacomo Puccini's "Crisantemi" for a full house — of plants.
https://t.co/gIhW52O2wB

name: NPR
text:
Sudan Archives is a truly singular artist — inspired by Irish and African music, especially Sudanese music. Watch her songs, backed by violin and cello, take on new meaning.
https://t.co/kPxq7eRCEO

name: NPR
text:
Phoebe Bridgers's second solo album, 'Punisher,' is here.

She spoke with NPR about her collaborations, cribbing from her favorite artists, and writing one of her most evocative lines — which was inspired by a visit to the nutritionist.
https://t.co/eyScZExQeu

name: NPR
text:
California Gov. Gavin Newsom, Arnold Schwarzenegger and 3 other former governors of the Golden State appear in a new video to stress the importance of mask-wearing to curb the spread of the coronavirus.
https://t.co/nzTUiRyYkt

name: NPR
text:
"These statements are just the beginning. Because now you have really opened yourself up to be scrutinized.” 

@preciselyalexis & @TracyJan speak with @OSTtalk about the significance of companies publicly backing Black Lives Matter. https://t.co/8HSqzoTtZ6

name: NPR
text:
When musician Thao Nguyen was invited to play a show in Vietnam, she convinced her mother, who escaped the country during the war, to come along.

Nguyen revisits the experience with her band the Get Down Stay Down's new album, "Temple."
https://t.co/qBB1JotU4P

name: NPR
text:
Mosquito-borne and water-borne diseases are common during the monsoon season in Mumbai's overcrowded slums, as is flooding. So authorities usually spend the spring helping communities prepare.

But this year, the pandemic is making that tough.
https://t.co/keC4S04dDe

name: NPR
text:
Released in the final hours of Juneteenth, "Black Parade" is the latest example of Beyoncé using her pop domination to put Black pride front and center. 
https://t.co/GseEpeP7v5

name: NPR
text:
The WNBA has announced plans for a shortened season to be held in Florida, beginning in late July. The league's 12 teams will all train and play in the same location.
https://t.co/qcbw00AIQO

name: NPR
text: "While we don't know what lies ahead right now, I'd say we never truly do in life," says musician Bobby Bare. "We always have a choice, every day, to either live in fear of what might be, or take it day by day." https://t.co/iVpfwCPuG2

name: NPR
text:
Archaeologists have found a massive ring structure made of prehistoric shafts near Stonehenge.

They say it dates back to 2500 B.C.E. and is "significantly larger than any comparative prehistoric monument we know of in Britain, at least."
https://t.co/rkErTj2w14

name: NPR
text:
Police cleared demonstrators with chemical agents in Lafayette Square near the White House last night, after protesters attempted to pull down a statue of former President Andrew Jackson — who was a slaveholder and signed into law the Indian Removal Act.
https://t.co/luM0HzHAr6

name: NPR
text:
Victoria is the first person in the U.S. with a genetic disorder to be treated with the gene-editing tool CRISPR.

One year into treatment, it appears to be working.

"We need this right now more than ever, you know?" she says. "It's a blessing."
https://t.co/uJ1X7IPFf6

name: NPR
text: RT @rdlewis: Aviation has a problem it's wrestled with for decades... when pilots continue a flight into bad weather. It's partly to blame in the Kobe Bryant helicopter crash. What can the industry do? My latest for @NPR: https://t.co/4zHPaZ3HfI
